transcript.content: Wilford Guy Interview REDACTIONS FINAL

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Stating for the record your name, the crime of conviction that you're serving all this time for, how old you were at the time, and how much time you served.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: My name is Wilford Guy. I was convicted of second degree murder. I was 18 years old. I had just got out of Louisiana Training Institution on my 18th birthday and I stood on the street for six months.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How much time have you served?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I'm going into my 34th year.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, you're 52 now?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I'm 52, yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: As I said earlier, I want to learn about your life and your experiences, but I want to start with your childhood. Can you tell me a little bit about the folks who raised you?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: My grandmother raised me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Can you tell me where you were raised?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: New Orleans, Louisiana. St. Bernard Housing Project. It's known as Columbia Park.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about your grandmother.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Her name was Albertha Kennedy. She raised me from childhood until I caught my crime. I was in and out of juvenile facilities.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What about any brothers and sisters?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I'm the oldest. It was two of us. When I was locked up, I had three sisters that my mom had. I'm the oldest of five.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Since you've gone to the juvenile facility, your mom had more kids?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, you're the oldest of five. Are you still in touch with your siblings?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I'm in touch with one of them.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Which one?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Mashonda Guy. They got another one, Aziza, every now and then she might answer the phone. I got one that's, she got mental problems. She just left from out of Laplace. She going to Shreveport. She got disability problems. She getting monthly checks.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I'm assuming your grandmother's deceased, but is that true?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you ever have a relationship with your mother?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yeah, I had a relationship with her, but my grandmother kind of like raised me up.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Were their men in your grandmother's life that came into your life?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: No, see what the problem was, my grandmother took me from my mama because I had a stepdaddy. He used to beat us. He used to beat me and my little brother and I wound up going to the foster home.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I understand.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I went to school, Phillips Junior High and I reported and I showed the social worker I had belt marks, extension cords where he whipped me and they took me from my mama and put me in a foster home. My grandmother wound up getting custody.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: My goodness. How old were you when that happened?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I was like 15. No, I was like. That happened when I came out of, that was before I went to I went to Scotlandville.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You must have been young at that point.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yeah, I was like 12 or 13 years old.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Was the abuse ever sexual?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: No, he was just beating me, just beating me, talking about, make me stand in the corner. He used to try to teach me how to turn the clock. How to learn the time and if we get late for school, he use to beat us for no reason.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, he was just an abusive man. Did your mother ever try to intervene to protect you kids?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: She was in love with him.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: All right. So, the school social worker decides that they need to take you out of that situation. What about your little brother? Did they take him too?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: He here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Your little brother's here in Angola?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yeah. His name Terence Guy. He here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Can I ask you something? You've had a lot of years to think back on that childhood experience. Do you think the abuse has something to do with why you ended up being here?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir. I ain't have no father. I had a grandmother raise me from all the way until I came to Angola.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Aside from not having a father, the fact that you were abused. Did that lead to you acting out and getting in trouble with the law?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, tell me a little bit about that that. What got you to Scotlandville?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I was with, I was going to Phillips Junior High and we used to like going to football games. I had a group of dudes I was with, we throwed rocks at a bus, and the rocks hit the bus and broke the glass, it hit one of the girls and cut her head, so they had sent me to LTI for like three years. The other dude got juvenile life. They had five of us throwing rocks at a bus. That's what had me going to Louisiana Training Institution, which is known as LTI.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok, so what happened to the girl?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: A rock hit the glass and it hit her in the head and she had a knot on her head, so they charged us with aggravated assault.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok, I got it. So, you spent three years there. Tell me about that.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I had to survive. I was fighting every day. I had a good social worker. I was fighting every day. One time when I was supposed to get out, it was late. The social worker had to call them and tell them I was supposed to be released, and they didn't know nothing about it. They wasn't keeping a record, but when they got is straight. I wound up getting out. I had to survive. Every day I was fighting.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. My understanding is that the guards weren't very helpful. In fact, they used to make the situation worse. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about that.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: The guard used to tell us, if y'all got something on y'all mind, y'all go in the other room and fight. Once y'all fight, it's over with.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: With school before that? How did you like school before that happened, so before you were 15, was school a place that you did well in?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I was an outpatient. I was going to see the doctor. I was taking medication. I was in special ed.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That's ok. So, from the age of 15, aside from the six months that you had on the street when you were released, you spent your entire life incarcerated?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Aside from your grandmother, was there any other adult who took an interest in you, wanted to help you, like a teacher or somebody who you thought you could trust and look up to?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: They had a teacher named Ms. Melissa Hall. That was in my junior high.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about her.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: She used to teach me and told me that if I had any problems let her know. She came and met my grandmother. My grandmother said well I'm trying to do the best I can do with him.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What brought your little brother here?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Second degree murder.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. So, highest grade of school was that eleventh grade for you?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I stopped in the eleventh grade. But when

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, tenth grade was the last grade for you.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: No, I was in my last year of high school, special Ed at John Mac. When I got here, I wound up getting a GED.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok, you got your GED. Ok, great. I'm assuming you don't have any children. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I don't have no children.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you remember the very first time you were arrested? Was it for throwing rocks at the bus? Was that the first time you were arrested?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I was arrested for shop lifting.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Before that?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, just the shoplifting and then that, and then the six months you were out you got a murder charge.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Let me ask you this Wilford. If you could identify one reason that got you down this kind of spiral that you ended up on, what would it be?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Say that again.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: If you have to identify one cause that got you down the path that you're on, what do you think it would be?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Not having a father in my life to help my mama and my grandmother.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Were drugs and alcohol a part of your life?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: No sir. I just used to watch people do it every day.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, but it wasn't part of your life?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: No sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Let me ask you a question that you can just guess at. If this guy didn't come and take your hundred dollar bill, how do you imagine the rest of your life would have unfolded for you?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I probably would have went to college because I was playing football and baseball at John Mac.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you see yourself as having gone to college after that?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I want to move on to your life here at Angola. As a kid, you came here, but is there something else about your childhood that is important to shaping who you are now or important to me understanding your life that I didn't ask you about?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: At the foster home, after the social worker took us from my mama and put us in a foster home. They had a lady we used to call Big Mama that stayed in New Orleans East. She used to always make sure we get to school and help us out and told us whatever things we need, just to let her know. She was real nice to us. That kind of like helped out.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That was a good part of your childhood? Was it always you and your brother Terence?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: It was me and Terence and then they had Rochelle, Aziza, and then Roshanda came along, but I was incarcerated when they was born.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, you're older than your brother Terence right?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, you're a trustee. Is that right?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: No sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh. Ok. I thought you were a trustee.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I was a trustee in 2012. I lost it. I went up on the board last Thursday. They recommend me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, you might get it back soon?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: If you could go back in time, how old were you when you came here?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I was 18 years old. I was put in C Block.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Well, let's talk about that for a second. Do you remember the bus ride coming down here to Angola?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about what's going through your head.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: It was a long bus ride. We was chained up on the bus. Chained up with the shackles on our legs just coming here, and then when we got here. They took all our personal stuff and gave us state clothes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What were your first few weeks like here?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: In C Block, they had a man who was a colonel I talked to him the other day, he is a colonel who retired. He said either you are going to be a girl boy or you got to fight and be a man. He said go down the tier and you got to fight and do your thing. I caught a lot of write ups when I first come because I had to prove myself.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Fighting?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Fights. Some fights I got away with. The security turned their head and acted like they ain't seen nothing. They looked off.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Instead of breaking it up?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Instead of breaking it up. Look off, look away.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you find yourself getting injured?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: No. As I was here come to find out. I just didn't wear it. I wear a hearing aid. I got some nerve damage in both ears.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: From fighting, you think?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: No, I'm saying in '96 they had a man named Mr. William Cox. He was an ear, nose, and throat specialist from Baton Rouge. He test my ears and said man, he told me, you're going deaf. You can't hear. And then when I went to Lafayette. They had an audiologist.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: A lady test both my ears and said you ain't faking. You got nerve damage in both ears. That's gon be there for the rest of your life. So, I've been wearing a hearing aid since August 13, 1996 all the way to now. It got a little mic with the things. Some people make fun. The majority of the time, I just don't wear it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You seem to be hearing me no problem.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I can hear you close up. I can respond too.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Mr. Guy, let me ask you a question about a particular thing because one of the complaints that came out of LTI and Tulula and places like that, the juvenile facilities is that many of those boys ended up with perforated ear drums from the guards hitting them on the side of their head.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: They would punch them. Hit them all upside the head.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did that happen a lot to you as a kid?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you think that might have had anything to do with your hearing loss?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Nine out of ten it did.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, you come here and you feel the need to fight all the time to survive.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: You got to survive. It was still the bloodiest penitentiary in the nation in the late '80's. I came October 5, 1987. It was still considered as a worse prison.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. What was your typical day like? Did they put you in the field?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yeah, I worked in the field for like five or six years. I was put straight in the field.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What year did your brother get here?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: He came here in '94.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And how was that for you, to see your brother come here?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: It kind of messed me up. It kind of messed me up.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Were you able to at least show him the ropes and take care of him a little bit or did he have to kind of figure it out for himself?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: He pretty smart. He came in and got a GED. I showed him a little things and then, he picked up from there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Can you describe your day now? What's your typical routine when you wake up in the morning to when you go to bed at night? What do you do?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I wake up in the morning. I wash my face and brush my teeth. Make me a cup of coffee. I go outside on the walk and sweep and mop the walk. I'm a janitor on the Cypress Walk, due to my disability.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How long do you do that for?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: They was working me seven days a week until the lawyer William Most stepped in and he filed a federal lawsuit for me because they was overworking me. He said they couldn't work me. You could only work 40 hours. They were working me seven days a week until he stepped in.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: William Most filed a federal lawsuit for me dealing with my disability because they got the telephone that's locked up downstairs. They getting a federal grant and handpicking who they want. I didn't know I was supposed to use the telephone. They got a TTY phone. So, Mr. William Most filed a federal lawsuit.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Are you part of any of the organizations here at Angola, any of the clubs?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I go to church regular. I like to go to church every Thursday and Saturday. New Destiny. Jimmy Robertson.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok, I know Mr. Robertson. Do you sing?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: No, I pass out coffee and tea before the service and at the end of the service. I'm like a deacon in the church.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok. I understand. Let me ask you this. When you look back on what happened, the crime that brought you here, going after the guy that stole your money in the neighborhood. What are your feelings about it?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: It really wasn t supposed to happen. Everybody in the neighborhood knew both of us. I wish I can dig him out the ground and blow breath back in his body

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. I understand. It has also had a huge impact on your family. Your grandmother had to watch you go through that. Your brother. Who do you think had the hardest time watching you come up here?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: My grandmother. A lot of people used to always tell me from the neighborhood, if your grandmother still would be living you probably wouldn't even much be in there because she knew certain people she could go to try to help.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When did she pass away?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: 2000. On November 11, 2000.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you remember the last time you saw her?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: The last time I saw here was during my trial.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Was she at the trial?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yeah, she testified for me and everything. She called the police because I had ran off from the scene. By her working as a dispatcher, she called the police and let them know that I'm her grandson and I'm the one done the killing.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you call her and tell her what happened?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: She came on the scene. She told me, she said Papa, baby let me help you. Don't run. I just broke out running.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Is that your nickname, Papa?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I see it on your hand too. If you get before a parole board or a pardon board in this case and they ask you to tell them how you're rehabilitated. Why should they give you a second chance? If they ask these kinds of questions, what would you like them to know about you?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I got a GED. I ain't been in trouble in three years. The older I got, the mature I get. I try to stay out of trouble and do what security ask me. I got my GED and I got 52 certificates. I done took every self-help program here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: All of those things matter. What has been the hardest thing for you at Angola? What's the worst part of being here? I'm sure there are a lot of things, but what's the worst thing for you?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Waking up every morning with the same old routine. The food bad. I got a cousin who drive 18-wheelers. I told him I don't like to eat out the kitchen, so he send me a hundred dollars every month or every other month. I go to the store and eat out of my box. The food is real terrible.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: A lot of the people here don't eat the food, right? They buy their own food.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: They buy their own. I don't put money in the clubs. I buy everything out the store. That's just a one night meal. You buy three or four pieces of chicken with some gravy and rice, or red beans and rice, or macaroni. When you eat that you don't got nothing when you look in the box. I can go buy 35 noodle soups. That's 35 nights of eating with chips.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Okay. How have you coped over the years with the idea that you might not be released? When you see people die in here at Angola. How do you cope?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: You never know. The medical is really poor here. You got to catch sick call at least ten times before you can see a doctor. You don't see a doctor until 60 days later or almost 70 days later. It's real poor here. They got an African group out of Lafayette.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: She ain't there no more, Ms. Elizabeth Compa. The Promise of Justice in New Orleans and the people in Lafayette they interviewed a whole lot of us. They got a trial date, October 9th. That's dealing with the whole prison cause the medical real poor here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: The healthcare.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yeah, the healthcare real poor.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you think you'll ever get out Mr. Guy?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I'm praying. The only thing I do is ask God to give me another chance. I'm praying and asking that I do get some kind of relief.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Well let me tell you this. Of the various things that you've done, from your GED to the 52 certificates that you've gotten here or anything else. What stands out as the thing you're most proud of?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: That I was able to get me a GED and because I promised my mom before she died that I would finish high school, but I ain't had that chance. I had to come here and finish.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. I'm sorry. When did your mother die? I forgot that.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: We went to the funeral. She died March 24, 2014. Four years ago. We went to the funeral April 4, 2014 in New Orleans on St. Bernard Avenue in a church.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You went with your brother?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Both of us went in the same car.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Are you pretty close with him here in the prison? Do you find you spend time with each other?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yeah, he on a different yard. We'll meet and talk about certain things.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, let me ask you this. At some point, I'm hoping you'll be able to go before a pardon board and if you've got a good disciplinary record at that point let's say they say that yeah we're going to let you commute your sentence to a fixed term and go before a parole board and let's say the parole board lets you go. How do you think the rest of your life is going to be? What does that chapter of your life look like? What are you going to do?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Try to get me a job and live a normal life.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Would you go to New Orleans?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: I was born and raised there. I don't have nothing to hide. I'd go back because I got sisters there. Other than that, I'd go somewhere else.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Well, that's about all the questions I have for you. Is there something else that I should have asked you that I didn't? Something else that you wanted to talk about today?

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: That's it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Thank you very much Mr. Guy. I appreciate it.

transcript.speaker: Wilford
transcript.content: Yes sir.
